awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Mechanisms regulating intrinsic levels of antimicrobial resistance in planktonic cells and biofilms of commensal Neisseria
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Spelman College aims to characterize commensal Neisseria levels and mechanisms of antimicrobial resistance, in planktonic cells and cells forming biofilms, and whether these bacteria should be considered a reservoir for the spread of antimicrobial resistance genes.

Commensal bacteria persist inside or outside multicellular organisms, usually without causing harm. Several commensal Neisseria species live in the human oral and nasopharynx as part of a complex and diverse microbiome. They are related to the pathogenic N. meningitidis, an agent of meningitis, and N. gonorrhoeae, the agent of the sexually-transmitted disease gonorrhea. As much as pathogenic Neisseria are studied, commensal Neisseria are poorly characterized. Deciphering the factors and regulatory pathways affecting antimicrobial resistance in commensal Neisseria will elucidate the molecular mechanisms that evolved in commensal and pathogenic species. The goals of this study are to characterize antimicrobial resistance levels of planktonic cells, of cells in biofilms, and to identify the factors and regulatory mechanisms involved in antimicrobial resistance in these cell populations of commensal Neisseria species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The current NSF Research Initiation Award (#1800691), entitled “Mechanisms regulating intrinsic levels of antimicrobial resistance in planktonic cells and biofilms of commensal Neisseria”, led by Dr. Maira Goytia, in the Department of Biology at Spelman College (Atlanta, GA), had 3 main scientific objectives and 2 major broader impact objectives. Scientifically, the project focused on (1) characterizing the antimicrobial resistance profile of commensal Neisseria species, (2) quantifying their capacity to form biofilm, and (3) performing an analysis of AMR genes (using comparative genomics) and AMR gene expression profiles (using transcriptomics) of bacteria grown in the presence of subinhibitory concentrations of first line treatment antibiotics, ceftriaxone and azithromycin. Neisseria species are commonly found in the oral and nasopharynx in humans and do not cause disease, they are part of our normal flora that may help us prevent infection by pathogens and stimulate our immune system. Commensal Neisseria species are highly related to N. gonorrhoeae, a sexually-transmitted bacterium, that causes gonorrhea and is increasingly antimicrobial resistant, to the point that we may observe “untreatable gonorrhea” soon. These three scientific goals encompassed the need to better understand the interactions of commensal bacteria in the host and their capacity to act as AMR gene reservoirs. Indeed, we showed that several commensal Neisseria species displayed AMR profiles similar or stronger than strains of N. gonorrhoeae considered multi-drug resistant. In particular, these commensal strains displayed high antimicrobial resistance to ceftriaxone and azithromycin – drugs currently used to treat N. gonorrhoeae, and erythromycin, used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. This suggested that commensal Neisseria species carry AMR genes that are likely activated when grown in the presence of these drugs. We are currently in the process of analyzing gene expression data of 3 Neisseria species grown in the presence of different concentrations of ceftriaxone or azithromycin, to identify regulatory networks and genes activated or inactivated under these growth conditions. Alongside, we are also analyzing the genomes of these 3 species to identify candidate genes that increase bacterial survivability in the presence of antimicrobials. This is still a work in progress, that we hope to report on in the near future. Our work also focused on characterizing the capacity of commensal species to form biofilms which are large agglomerates of bacteria enclosed in an external matrix composed of sugars, proteins, and nucleic acid, that help bacteria survive in unfavorable conditions, and provide an environment for greater gene exchange, where AMR genes could be exchanged between commensal and pathogenic bacteria. 

 

The Broader Impact objectives involved (1) training students in microbiology research and helping them think and study the antimicrobial resistance worldwide public health crisis, and (2) perform outreach activities for children of the metro Atlanta area. Over the course of the 4.5 years of funding, we supported 18 undergraduate students performing research in the lab during the school year and as full-time student researchers over the summer. These students developed technical and conceptual skill sets, as they developed their research project, designed and performed experiments, analyzed their results and drew conclusions. Students honed their quantitative, analytical, and critical-thinking skills, and matured their scientific reasoning as well as their written and oral communication skills. Thirteen students presented their work at Spelman’s Research Day symposium, including a few who earned first prize in their category, 6 students orally presented their work at ABRCMS, including 3 who obtained Travel Awards; 3 students are co-authors of a peer-reviewed manuscript published in MDPI Antibiotics (Goytia et al., MDPI Antibiotics, 2021). In addition, we developed outreach activities at the Atlanta Science Festival in 2018 and 2019, for children and their families, where faculty and students talk about their career and academic journeys, and are often seen as role models by the children. Spelman students interacted via zoom during the pandemic with 4th and 5th graders in Roanoke, VA, to show them what working in a lab is like. Spelman students discussed their scientific interests and research projects, and their academic journeys, and the children asked many questions. Spelman Biology Students led a booth at the Atlanta Science Festival Expo twice, where they shared science experiments with 500 children and their families, and helped carry the panel discussion through Dr. Espy’s STEM GEMS symposium, at Spelman in 2019.

 

Thanks to this project, we (1) published two scientific articles, one peer-reviewed original manuscript with 3 undergraduate student co-authors (Goytia et al., MDPI Antibiotics, 2021), and one review paper on the importance of surveilling commensal Neisseria as sources of AMR genes for N. gonorrhoeae (Goytia & Wadsworth, mBio, 2022), and (2) we provided undergraduate minority students the opportunity to design and develop research and (3) present their findings at national conferences and exposed over 300 children to scientific discussions, career paths, and the college experience in STEM.
